spec-ref.item: J.1 #01. A stylesheet may now consist of multiple packages.

category.spec: J.1 #01. A stylesheet may now consist of multiple packages.
J.1 #01. A stylesheet may now consist of multiple packages.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #02.a. A mode may be declared to be streamable, and rules are given that constrain what the template rules in a streamable mode can do.

category.spec: J.1 #02.a. A mode may be declared to be streamable, and rules are given that constrain what the template rules in a streamable mode can do.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #02.b. An xsl:mode declaration may define the action to be taken when there is no matching template rule, and the action to be taken when there are multiple matching template rules.

category.description: Modes with warning-on-no-match, on-multiple-match and on-no-match
category.spec: J.1 #02.b. An xsl:mode declaration may define the action to be taken when there is no matching template rule, and the action to be taken when there are multiple matching template rules.

category.description: Modes with warning-on-no-match, on-multiple-match and on-no-match
category.spec: J.1 #02.b. An xsl:mode declaration may define the action to be taken when there is no matching template rule, and the action to be taken when there are multiple matching template rules.

test-set.description: Modes with warning-on-no-match, on-multiple-match and on-no-match
Modes with warning-on-no-match, on-multiple-match and on-no-match

spec-ref.item: J.1 #02.c. An xsl:mode declaration may indicate that the template rules in a given mode are designed to process typed (schema-validated) nodes only, or untyped nodes only. It may also indicate that element names appearing in match patterns for the mode are only to match elements in the source document that have been validated against the corresponding element declarations in the schema.

category.spec: J.1 #02.c. An xsl:mode declaration may indicate that the template rules in a given mode are designed to process typed (schema-validated) nodes only, or untyped nodes only. It may also indicate that element names appearing in match patterns for the mode are only to match elements in the source document that have been validated against the corresponding element declarations in the schema.

J.1 #02.c. An xsl:mode declaration may indicate that the template rules in a given mode are designed to process typed (schema-validated) nodes only, or untyped nodes only. It may also indicate that element names appearing in match patterns for the mode are only to match elements in the source document that have been validated against the corresponding element declarations in the schema.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #02.d. A default mode can be declared for a stylesheet module, making it easier to reuse existing stylesheet modules to construct a composite stylesheet.

category.spec: J.1 #02.d. A default mode can be declared for a stylesheet module, making it easier to reuse existing stylesheet modules to construct a composite stylesheet.
J.1 #02.d. A default mode can be declared for a stylesheet module, making it easier to reuse existing stylesheet modules to construct a composite stylesheet.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #03.b. The xsl:iterate instruction allows iterative processing of a sequence, with the ability for the processing of one item to depend on the results of processing of previous items, and with the ability to terminate the iteration before all the items in the sequence have been processed.

category.spec: J.1 #03.b. The xsl:iterate instruction allows iterative processing of a sequence, with the ability for the processing of one item to depend on the results of processing of previous items, and with the ability to terminate the iteration before all the items in the sequence have been processed.

J.1 #03.b. The xsl:iterate instruction allows iterative processing of a sequence, with the ability for the processing of one item to depend on the results of processing of previous items, and with the ability to terminate the iteration before all the items in the sequence have been processed.

J.1 #03.b. The xsl:iterate instruction allows iterative processing of a sequence, with the ability for the processing of one item to depend on the results of processing of previous items, and with the ability to terminate the iteration before all the items in the sequence have been processed.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #03.c. The xsl:merge instruction allows several input sequences to be merged into a single output sequence, based on the value of a merge key.

category.spec: J.1 #03.c. The xsl:merge instruction allows several input sequences to be merged into a single output sequence, based on the value of a merge key.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #03.d. The xsl:fork instruction allows multiple results to be computed during a single pass of a streamed input document.

category.spec: J.1 #03.d. The xsl:fork instruction allows multiple results to be computed during a single pass of a streamed input document.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #04.a. The new top-level declaration xsl:accumulator is introduced. An accumulator represents information about a node in a document that can be computed during a streamed pass over the document, starting at the start and ending at that node.

category.spec: J.1 #04.a. The new top-level declaration xsl:accumulator is introduced. An accumulator represents information about a node in a document that can be computed during a streamed pass over the document, starting at the start and ending at that node.

J.1 #04.a. The new top-level declaration xsl:accumulator is introduced. An accumulator represents information about a node in a document that can be computed during a streamed pass over the document, starting at the start and ending at that node.

J.1 #04.a. The new top-level declaration xsl:accumulator is introduced. An accumulator represents information about a node in a document that can be computed during a streamed pass over the document, starting at the start and ending at that node.

J.1 #04.a. The new top-level declaration xsl:accumulator is introduced. An accumulator represents information about a node in a document that can be computed during a streamed pass over the document, starting at the start and ending at that node.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #04.b. New functions copy-of and snapshot are provided, to enable streaming applications to operate in 'windowing' mode, where the input document is divided into a sequence of small subtrees processed one at a time.

category.spec: J.1 #04.b. New functions copy-of and snapshot are provided, to enable streaming applications to operate in 'windowing' mode, where the input document is divided into a sequence of small subtrees processed one at a time.

J.1 #04.b. New functions copy-of and snapshot are provided, to enable streaming applications to operate in 'windowing' mode, where the input document is divided into a sequence of small subtrees processed one at a time.

J.1 #04.b. New functions copy-of and snapshot are provided, to enable streaming applications to operate in 'windowing' mode, where the input document is divided into a sequence of small subtrees processed one at a time.

J.1 #04.b. New functions copy-of and snapshot are provided, to enable streaming applications to operate in 'windowing' mode, where the input document is divided into a sequence of small subtrees processed one at a time.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #05.a. The xsl:try instruction allows recovery from dynamic errors.

category.spec: J.1 #05.a. The xsl:try instruction allows recovery from dynamic errors.
J.1 #05.a. The xsl:try instruction allows recovery from dynamic errors.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #05.b. A new xsl:evaluate instruction is provided, to allow evaluation of XPath expressions constructed dynamically from strings, or read from a source document.

category.spec: J.1 #05.b. A new xsl:evaluate instruction is provided, to allow evaluation of XPath expressions constructed dynamically from strings, or read from a source document.
J.1 #05.b. A new xsl:evaluate instruction is provided, to allow evaluation of XPath expressions constructed dynamically from strings, or read from a source document.
J.1 #05.b. A new xsl:evaluate instruction is provided, to allow evaluation of XPath expressions constructed dynamically from strings, or read from a source document.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #05.c. The xsl:assert instruction allows arbitrary assertions about the state of variables or the input document, improving testability and robustness.

category.spec: J.1 #05.c. The xsl:assert instruction allows arbitrary assertions about the state of variables or the input document, improving testability and robustness.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #06. Text nodes within a sequence constructor may now contain text value templates (XPath expressions enclosed in curly brackets), if this is enabled by setting expand-text='yes' on an enclosing element.

category.spec: J.1 #06. Text nodes within a sequence constructor may now contain text value templates (XPath expressions enclosed in curly brackets), if this is enabled by setting expand-text='yes' on an enclosing element.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #07. The syntax of patterns has been generalized. Patterns may now match any item (not only nodes).

category.spec: J.1 #07. The syntax of patterns has been generalized. Patterns may now match any item (not only nodes).
J.1 #07. The syntax of patterns has been generalized. Patterns may now match any item (not only nodes).

spec-ref.item: J.1 #08. A new datatype, called a map, has been introduced, together with supporting functions, operators, and type syntax.

category.spec: J.1 #08. A new datatype, called a map, has been introduced, together with supporting functions, operators, and type syntax.
J.1 #08. A new datatype, called a map, has been introduced, together with supporting functions, operators, and type syntax.

J.1 #08. A new datatype, called a map, has been introduced, together with supporting functions, operators, and type syntax.
J.1 #08. A new datatype, called a map, has been introduced, together with supporting functions, operators, and type syntax.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.b. The xsl:copy instruction now has a select attribute, which is convenient when it is used inside a function where there is no context item.

category.spec: J.1 #09.b. The xsl:copy instruction now has a select attribute, which is convenient when it is used inside a function where there is no context item.
J.1 #09.b. The xsl:copy instruction now has a select attribute, which is convenient when it is used inside a function where there is no context item.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.c. Composite keys are supported in xsl:for-each-group.

category.spec: J.1 #09.c. Composite keys are supported in xsl:for-each-group.
J.1 #09.c. Composite keys are supported in xsl:for-each-group.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.d. The override attribute of xsl:function is renamed override-extension-function, retaining the old name as a deprecated synonym.

category.description: Renaming of override attribute into override-extension-function
category.spec: J.1 #09.d. The override attribute of xsl:function is renamed override-extension-function, retaining the old name as a deprecated synonym.

test-set.description: Renaming of override attribute into override-extension-function

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.d. Two new attributes have been added to xsl:function to provide increased scope for optimization: identity-sensitive and cache.

category.spec: J.1 #09.d. Two new attributes have been added to xsl:function to provide increased scope for optimization: identity-sensitive and cache.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.f. The rule requiring xsl:import declarations to precede all other declarations in a stylesheet module has been removed.

category.description: Order of xsl:import with preceding declarations
category.spec: J.1 #09.f. The rule requiring xsl:import declarations to precede all other declarations in a stylesheet module has been removed.

test-set.description: Order of xsl:import with preceding declarations

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.g. Composite keys are supported in xsl:for-each-group.

category.spec: J.1 #09.g. Composite keys are supported in xsl:for-each-group.
J.1 #09.g. Composite keys are supported in xsl:for-each-group.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.h. A new attribute on xsl:message allows specification of the error code to be returned with terminate='yes' is specified.

category.spec: J.1 #09.h. A new attribute on xsl:message allows specification of the error code to be returned with terminate='yes' is specified.
J.1 #09.h. A new attribute on xsl:message allows specification of the error code to be returned with terminate='yes' is specified.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.j. An xsl:template declaration may contain an xsl:context-item element to declare the required type of the context item when the template is called.

category.spec: J.1 #09.j. An xsl:template declaration may contain an xsl:context-item element to declare the required type of the context item when the template is called.
J.1 #09.j. An xsl:template declaration may contain an xsl:context-item element to declare the required type of the context item when the template is called.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.k. An empty xsl:value-of instruction with no select attribute is now permitted; its effect is to construct a zero-length text node.

category.spec: J.1 #09.k. An empty xsl:value-of instruction with no select attribute is now permitted; its effect is to construct a zero-length text node.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #09.l. The xsl:variable and xsl:param elements may now specify static='yes'

category.spec: J.1 #09.l. The xsl:variable and xsl:param elements may now specify static='yes'
J.1 #09.l. The xsl:variable and xsl:param elements may now specify static='yes'
J.1 #09.l. The xsl:variable and xsl:param elements may now specify static='yes'

spec-ref.item: J.1 #10. New functions are available to import and export data in JSON format.

category.spec: J.1 #10. New functions are available to import and export data in JSON format.
J.1 #10. New functions are available to import and export data in JSON format.

spec-ref.item: J.1 #14. The rule that effectively prevented references to external documents in [xsl:]use-when expressions has been removed.

category.spec: J.1 #14. The rule that effectively prevented references to external documents in [xsl:]use-when expressions has been removed.
